title: Austistic boy ‘abducted’ and taken to Russia by his mum
text:
Ian Kettlewell’s son Myles was allegedly abducted by the boy’s mother (Picture: @BringMylesHome)

A father claims his autistic son has been abducted and taken to Russia by his mother, where he cannot speak the language.

BT engineer Ian Kettlewell, 35, claims he won a court ruling in June to prevent his ex-partner from taking their son Myles to live in her homeland.

He says she picked him up from school on September 30 and caught a flight from Heathrow just ten hours later, despite his attempt to put a block on his son’s passport.

Mr Kettlewell is now seeking a High Court order to try and get the Russian authorities to intervene so Myles can be returned to his home in Lowestoft, Suffolk.

He now fears that Myles who was diagnosed with autism in 2017 will be feeling lonely and isolated.

Mr Kettlewell described the loss of Myles as a ‘nightmare’ which has left his world ‘turned upside down.’

Ian Kettlewell’s son Myles was allegedly abducted by the boy’s mother (Picture: @BringMylesHome)

‘My son is not a possession’ (Picture: @BringMylesHome)

He said: ‘My son is a not a possession; he is a human being with rights and feelings. I miss him. I fear for him. And I desperately want him back home where he belongs and where he can be himself.

‘It has turned my life upside down. It’s something that happens in a film. I keep waking up and wishing it was just a bad dream. It is better for me to think he is having an adventure and is enjoying it. It is heart-wrenching and I feel helpless.’

Waveney MP Peter Aldous who represents Lowestoft has confirmed he is liaising with the Foreign Office and has written to foreign secretary Dominic Raab to seek assistance in bringing Myles back to the UK.

Mr Kettlewell said he and his former partner split up in 2013, and were granted joint custody of their son with 50:50 access in September last year.

His partner who he is not naming had a job and a home in the Lowestoft area, so that Myles could split his time between them.

Mr Kettlewell said that courts granted him permission to be the keeper of his son’s two passports to reduce the risk of him being abducted to his mother’s homeland.

He claimed that the courts rejected an application by his former partner in June for her to be able to take Myles to live permanently in Russia with her.

He said that Myles’ mother returned to court in July to request permission to take him on holiday to Russia. (Picture: @BringMylesHome)

Mr Kettlewell said: ‘The courts decided that it was in Myles’ best interest to remain in the UK with his loving family and the comfort and security his homeland provides. ‘

He said that Myles’ mother returned to court in July to request permission to take him on holiday to Russia.

Mr Kettlewell said: ‘Despite raising my natural concern regarding his safety, I was given little choice by the court but to agree to this. She therefore took Myles on holiday, and returned, albeit a day later than what had been agreed.

‘Since returning to the UK, she retained Myles’ passport and refused to hand it back to me. Once more, I had no choice but to apply to the court for an enforcement order to guarantee the safe return of his passport to me.’

He said they were due to go back to court on October 3 to allow him to seek an order, forcing her to return the passport.

Mr Kettlewell said he dropped off his son at his school as normal on September 30 and later called to arrange a meeting with a staff member and his former partner to deliver court paperwork regarding the passport handover.

But he was then told that she had taken Myles out of the school just before 1pm.

Mr Kettlewell feared immediately that she was planning to take him to Russia and dialled 999 at 3.45pm to report the ‘potential abduction’.

Mr Kettlewell said he was worried that his son’s autism would make it particularly difficult for him being forced to start a new life in Russia (Picture: @BringMylesHome)

He requested that a ‘crucial block’ be put on Myles’ passport, but the passport was not blocked until 9.30pm which was too late to stop him from joining his mother on a 10.45pm flight to Russia that night.

Advertisement

Mr Kettlewell said he was worried that his son’s autism would make it particularly difficult for him being forced to start a new life in Russia.

He said: ‘One of the greatest things you can feel when growing up is safe and secure-nothing to worry about, loved and content.

‘This is true for all children, but especially true for those children with additional needs. Myles was diagnosed in 2017 with autism and is lucky to be in a mainstream school that supports his educational and additional needs brilliantly well.

‘A child with autism’s general well-being relies on structure, familiarity and routine. For Myles, stability is quite simply all about being at home where he is able to enjoy the simplest of pleasures: sharing his love of ‘space and exploration’ with me or enjoying the comfort of watching the birds in the garden.

‘Comfort for Myles is certainly not about flying to an unfamiliar country and being dumped in a land of strangers where he is unable to speak the language.’

Mr Kettlewell has now launched a campaign to raise funds to help pay the legal costs of bringing his son home, as he is unable to get Legal Aid. The campaign with a £50,000 target had already had donations of nearly £9,000 from well-wishers.
